keywords.term: PASH syndrome, pyoderma gangrenosum, acne, and suppurative hidradenitis syndrome

p.s: significant repigmentation in vitiligo was reported with tofacitinib citrate treatment (Craiglow et al., 2015).
A case of reversal of alopecia areata has been observed with baricitinib treatment (Jabbari et al., 2015).
In summary, we demonstrate a substantial benefit from ruxolitinib therapy in a case of chilblain LE.
Our observation supports the idea that JAK/STAT inhibition provides a promising therapeutic approach for the treatment of cutaneous autoimmune diseases, particularly LE.
DW reports research support and honorary payments from Novartis.
JW, NvH, JM, MV, and TB state no conflicts of interest.
Punwani N, Scherle P, Flores R, Shi J, Liang J, Yeleswaram S, et

The familial form of hidradenitis suppurativa (HS), also known as acne inversa (AI), is an autosomal dominant autoinflammatory genodermatosis caused by mutations in the genes encoding g-secretase subunits (Ingram and Piguet, 2013).

Recently, HS has been described as a triad with acne and pyoderma gangrenosum (PG), so-called PASH (pyoderma gangrenosum, acne, and suppurative hidradenitis) syndrome, and increased number of CCTG microsatellite repeats in the promoter region of PSTPIP1 was suggested to be associated with the phenotype (Braun-Falco et al., 2012).

In this study, we characterized an extended multigenerational Iranian family, including 24 affected and 32 unaffected individuals, presenting with manifestations of HS, acne, and PG in an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance (Figure 1a).
This study was approved by the Institutional Review Board of Kariminejad-Najmabadi Pathology and Genetics Center, Tehran.
Clinical evaluation of the affected individuals revealed HS and acne with different degrees of severity and extent in the spectrum of symptoms (Figure 1 and Supplementary Table S1 online).
The clinical features were documented in the Hospital of Kerman University of Sciences in nine patients, as detailed in Supplementary Table S1; among them, three patients had a history of PG.
DNA was isolated from 13 affected and 10 unaffected members of the extended family from peripheral blood leukocytes after a written, informed consent.

Mutation analysis was first performed by PCR amplification of the promoter region as well as all 15 exons and flanking intronic sequences of PSTPIP1 as the candidate gene previously shown to harbor mutations with PG and acne with pyogenic sterile arthritis (Wise et al., 2002).
One additional primer pair was designed to investigate the possibility of increased number of CCTG microsatellite repeats in the promoter region of PSTPIP1.
No pathogenic variants were detected in the coding region of this gene.

Sequencing of the promoter region showed (CCTG) 5 repeat as normal allele size, and thus, no increase in repeats of the CCTG microsatellite motif within 545 nucleotides of the 5 0 side of the ATG start codon was noted (Supplementary Figure S1 online).
In the next step, whole genome single nucleotide polymorphism genotyping was applied using an Illumina Humancoreexome-12v1-1 array (Illumina, San Diego, CA).
Linkage analysis resulted in the identification of genomic intervals with LOD scores >2 on chromosomes 1, 11, and 20 (Figure 2a and Supplementary Table S2 online).

Analysis of key individuals in the pedigree with flanking single nucleotide polymorphisms revealed a conserved haplotype in chromosome 1q23.2 in affected individuals but not in the controls (Supplementary Figure S2 online).

Whole exome sequencing was performed on the proband's DNA, and a total of 20 rare sequence variants were detected in the genomic intervals on chromosomes 1, 11, and 20 (Supplementary Table S3 online).
These variants were prioritized according to gene function and expression, mutation type, bioinformatics predictions, and frequency in our in-house ethnicspecific control panel.
Candidate prioritization resulted in selection of eight candidate genes (SELENBP1, HRNR, DAP3, GPATCH4, NCSTN, DDR2, AHNAK, and TTC24) consistent with the autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance.

Cosegregation studies further narrowed the possible candidates to two rare heterozygous variants, one in NCSTN and one in TTC24; all affected individuals were heterozygous, whereas the healthy individuals showed wild-type genotype.

The variant in NCSTN, c.1635C>G (p.Tyr545*) (Figure 2b), leads to a premature termination codon, whereas the c.888G>A variant in TTC24 affects a splice site at 5 0 border of exon 8 and was considered a putative splicing variant.
To examine the latter possibility, the effect of c.888G>A in TTC24 was evaluated at the mRNA level.
PCR amplification using flanking primers revealed no difference between sizes of the amplicons spanning exons 7e9 in the affected and healthy individuals.
Therefore, the c.888G>A variant in TTC24 does not have a major effect on RNA splicing that excluded this variant from further study.
Based on these findings, the c.1635C>G (p.Tyr545*) nonsense variant in the NCSTN gene was considered as the cause of the phenotype in this large family (Figure 2b).
During the course of our study, Duchatelet et al. (2015) reported a truncating variant in NCSTN as the gene responsible for HS, acne, and PG.

In their study, PSTPIP1, PSEN1, PSENEN, and NCSTN, genes previously reported to be mutated in patients with HS (Miskinyte et al., 2012;Pink et al., 2013), were investigated by Sanger sequencing, and a heterozygous frameshift deletion, c.344_351del (p.Thr115Asn*20), in the NCSTN gene was suggested as the causative mutation in one patient with so-called PASH syndrome.
In their study, the proband was an adopted child, and no family studies were performed.
Our study now extends these findings to a large multiplex pedigree with 24 affected individuals with HS, acne, and PG.
It should be noted that PG was present only in three of the nine patients attesting to the phenotypic heterogeneity in this family.
Consequently, PASH syndrome is not a genetically distinct entity, but rather belongs to the spectrum of gsecretase-related disorders, potentially caused by mutations in different genes.

NCSTN encodes nicastrin, one of the three subunits of g-secretase, a transmembrane endoprotease complex that catalyzes the cleavage of many transmembrane proteins, such as amyloid precursor, and E-and N-cadherin, as well as Notch receptors (Lu et al., 2014).
g-Secretase maintains skin appendages through Notch signaling involving both autonomous and nonautonomous signaling (Pan et al., 2004).

Recently, nonsense and truncating mutations in genes encoding gsecretase subunits (NCSTN, PSENEN, and PSEN1) have been reported in cases of HS or familial AI (Wang et al., 2010), and here extended to a large family also with PG.

How the mutations in the g-secretase genes elicit the autoinflammatory phenotypes is not clear, but it has been recently demonstrated that tumor necrosis factor-a and IL-10 levels were elevated in patients with HS with NCSTN mutations, possibly contributing to the chronic, recurrent in these skin conditions (Wang, 2015).
Thus, PG may be part of the autoinflammatory spectrum, together with HS and acne.

Genetic studies have identified 21 distinct mutations in NCSTN, most of them associated with HS/acne inversa (Li et al., 2011;Liu et al., 2011;Nomura et al., 2013;Pink et al., 2011;Wang et al., 2010;Zhang et al., 2013).

To the best of our knowledge, the pathogenic variant identified in this study, c.1635C>G (p.Tyr545*) in NCSTN, is previously unreported, providing strong evidence for the critical functional role of NCSTN in the phenotype of our patients.
et al., 2004;Pigatto et al., 1992).

Strong evidence has shown that the T helper-2 (Th2) cytokine, IL-13, is the dominant disease-causing factor in the pathogenesis of AD in mice (Nieuwenhuizen et al., 2009;Sivaprasad et al., 2010;Tazawa et al., 2004).
Hence, it is possible that patients with AD would benefit from
Figure1.
The pedigree and clinical features in the family with hidradenitis suppurativa (HS), acne, and pyoderma gangrenosum (PG).
(a) The pedigree is consistent with autosomal dominant inheritance (upper panel).

Skin lesions in affected family members include keloid scars in the armpit (b), in the buttocks (c), on the back (d), scarring as a result of fistules (e), HS (acne inversa) with abscesses and fistules in the neck (f), hyperpigmentation and scars symmetrically on the legs (g), hyperpigmentation and scars on the back (h), and scarring as a result of PG (i).
The patients consented to publication of these images.
Figure 2. Whole genome linkage analysis and mutation detection in NCSTN.
(a) Whole genome parametric linkage analysis (Merlin software, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI).
The top row shows the chromosome number and the vertical rows represent the LOD scores associated with each chromosome.
The highest LOD scores (>2) are located on chromosomes 1, 11, and 20 with a prominent genomic interval on chromosome 1.

(b) Chromatogram of the heterozygous truncating sequence variant c.1635C>G (p.Tyr545*), detected in NCSTN in an affected individual (top), compared with the wild-type sequence in an unaffected family member (bottom).

TO THE EDITOR Atopic dermatitis (AD) is an allergic skin condition that can result from intrinsic genetic factors or repetitive occupational damage.
